<div class="col2">  

^1^ *ỉr(.t) p(ȝ) wdn n N.t*  
*m hrw pn mỉ rʿ-nb*  
*ḏd-mdw*  

^1^ Performing the litany of Neith  
on this day like every day.  
Words spoken:  

</div>

<div class="col2">

*wdn n N.t wr.t*  
*mw.t-nṯr nb(.t) tȝ-sn.t*    
*m rn(.w)=s nb(.w)*  
*ḥr-tp ʿnḫ-wḏȝ-snb*  
*n nsw.t-bỉty*  
*(pr-ʿȝ <ʿnḫ> ḏ.t)|*  
  
Offering for Neith the great,   
Mother of God, Lady of Esna,   
in all her names,  
in addition to the life, prosperity, health    
for the King of Upper and Lower Egypt,  
(Pharaoh <living> forever)|   

</div>

**1**
<div class="col2">

*n N.t wr.t*  
*mw.t-nṯr nb(.t) tȝ-sn.t*
  
For Neith the great,  
Mother of God, Lady of Esna.

</div>

**2**
<div class="col2">

*n N.t wr.t*  
*mw.t-nṯr nb(.t) Zȝw*

</div>

**3**
<div class="col2">

*n N.t m tȝ hȝy.t*

</div>

**4**
<div class="col2">

*n N.t nb(.t) Zȝw*  
*ḥqȝ.t ʿȝ.t n Bȝq.t*

great ruler of Egypt (Baqet).

</div>

**5**
<div class="col2">

*n N.t*  
*n.t ỉr(.t) tȝ*

</div>

<div class="col2">

**12**
<div class="col2">

*n N.t*  
*wbn(.t) m Nwn*  
*ỉw tȝ m zmȝwy*  
   
For Neith  
who arose from Nun,  
while the earth was in darkness.  

</div>

**13**
<div class="col2">

*n N.t*  
*qrḥ.t ʿnḫ.t*  
*dỉ(.t) tp=s m Nwn*  
*ḥnʿ Ỉrỉ-tȝ*  
*wṯz Nw.t*  
   
For Neith,  
the living ancestor serpent,  
who showed herself in Nun  
together with Irita,  
who lifts up the sky (Nut).

</div>

**14**
<div class="col2">

*n N.t*  
*tmȝ.t ḥr.t-tp.t*  
*ḫp(r.t) m ḥȝ.t*  
*mw.t n ḏr-ʿ*  
^4^ *ms(.t) ms sy*  
  
For Neith  
maternal uraeus serpent,  
who came about in the beginning;  
mother of the very beginning,  
^4^ who bore the one who bore her.

</div>

**15**
<div class="col2">

*n N.t*  
*(ỉ)ʿrr.t ʿȝ.t*  
*r-ʿ nḥḥ ḏ.t*  
*mḥn.t nb(.t)*  
*ḫtỉ(.tw) ḥr rn=s*  
    
For Neith  
great uraeus,  
for all eternity,  
every uraeus goddess  
is inscribed with her name.[^fn-216-15] 

</div>

[^fn-216-15]: For this statement, see also paralleled in [Esna 212], A; [Esna 317], 3; explained by @sauneron-5, p. 286, n. t.

living-serpent who protects this land.

</div>

![](./images/216_6_25.png){width=15%}  
**25**
<div class="col2">

^6^ *n N.t*  
*ỉt mw.t*  
*ḫp(r) ḫnt*  
*pr m Nwn*  
*nỉ ḫp(r) wnn.t*  
  
^6^ For Neith  
father and mother,[^fn-216-25]  
who came about before,  
and emerged from Nun,  
before what exists had come into being.

</div>

[^fn-216-25]: In this verse, Neith's name is spelled as if it were "father" (scarab) and "mother" (vulture), exactly as Horapollo (chapter XII) mentioned for the goddess Neith-Athena.

**26**
<div class="col2">

*n N.t*  
*ỉt ỉt.w*  
*mw.t mw.wt*  
*ḫp(r.t)*   
*nỉ ḫpr ḫpr.w*  
  
For Neith  
father of fathers,  
mother of mothers,  
who came into being,  
before other beings came into being.

</div>

**27**
<div class="col2">

*n N.t pȝwty.t*  
*ỉr(.t) pȝwty.w*  
  
For Neith the Primeval,

</div>

**28**
<div class="col2">

*n N.t ỉh.t wr.t*  
*ms(.t) Rʿ*  
*ṯz(.t) pr.t *  
*n nṯr.w rmṯ.w*  
  
For Neith Ihet-weret,  
who gives birth to Re,  
and binds the seed   
of gods and humans. 

</div>

**29**
<div class="col2">

^7^ *n N.t-Rʿ.t-tȝ.wy*   
*m s.t=s nb*  
   
For Neith-Rattawy   
in all her thrones.[^fn-216-29]  

</div>

[^fn-216-29]: As primary consort of Montu, Rattawy was worshipped at all four sites around the Palladium of Thebes (Armant, Tod, Medamud, North Karnak). As such, she was also identified with the four goddesses of the Ogdoad, as well as the primeval Ihet-weret cow, which links her to Neith: @klotz-caesar, pp. 204-212.
